googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.year2020EarlyVotingEnds: November 1, 2020 (Some counties may vary, please confirm with your local election office)
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.earlyVotingNotesCombined:
* In-person absentee voting hours and date vary by municipality. Municipalities may choose to start in-person absentee voting as soon as ballots become available, in-person absentee voting then ends at 5 p.m. or the close of business (whichever is later) on the Sunday before the election.  Please check with your municipal clerk for regular office hours.
* If you apply for an absentee ballot in your municipal clerk's office, you must vote immediately, seal your ballot in the proper envelope, and return it to a member of the clerk's staff.  No ballots may be taken from the clerk's office.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.vbmAbsenteeBallotRules:
* For the November 3, 2020 election, most registered voters will receive an **absentee ballot application** in the mail.
* Any registered Wisconsin voter can request an absentee ballot and vote by mail.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.idRequirementsOvr: You can register to vote online if you have a Wisconsin driver's license or state ID card that shows your current address.  If not, you can still register to vote by mail or in person.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.idRequirementsSdr: Bring your Wisconsin driver's license or state ID card with you. If you don't have one, bring ONE photo ID that shows your name, and ONE document that shows your name and current address.  Acceptable documents include a utility bill, bank statement, paycheck, residential lease, or any government document that shows your name and address.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.registrationRules:
To register in Wisconsin you must:

  * be a citizen of the United States
  * be a resident of Wisconsin for at least 10 days
  * be 18 years old
  * not have been convicted of treason, felony or bribery, or if you have, your civil rights have been restored
  * not be incapable of understanding the objective of the elective process or under guardianship
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.earlyVotingByMailInfoCombined:
* In-person absentee voting hours and date vary by municipality. Municipalities may choose to start in-person absentee voting as soon as ballots become available, in-person absentee voting then ends at 5 p.m. or the close of business (whichever is later) on the Sunday before the election.  Please check with your municipal clerk for regular office hours.
* If you apply for an absentee ballot in your municipal clerk's office, you must vote immediately, seal your ballot in the proper envelope, and return it to a member of the clerk's staff.  No ballots may be taken from the clerk's office.
